The article writer makes it seem like the scientists don't know how close the rock will come to Earth.  The orbit of this rock is precisely known to within a few miles. The gravitation model of the fields around Earth includes the gravitational fields from Earth, the Moon, the Sun, Jupiter, Mars and Venus. Using finite element calculus and the motion of these bodies the orbit of this rock near Earth is known extremely well. What is imprecise is how close will its next encounter will be with Earth.

Approximately 25 million meteors enter the Earths atmosphere daily. We're fortunate that most of the planet is water and most of the meteors disintegrate in the upper atmosphere. It hasn't always been that way and as time goes on the odds against us being impacted narrow. Simply put, we're already several million years overdue for an extinction level event to nail us.

While science has been trying for decades to come up with something, anything, that might reduce the destructive capability of a larger meteor, given our current capability & everything in the foreseeable future, even the best ideas are wretchedly pathetic.

All that said & on that happy note, I'm going to live my life now, at its fullest, and enjoy it while I can. Like nuclear holocaust or a super-volcano, worrying about it gains me nothing. The only inevitability of which we have convincing evidence in life is that at some point, it ceases.
